Calculating magnetic declination for the current year
MD = 31° 33’ W of TN
AC = 2’ W
2012 – 1990 = 22 years 
22 × 2’ W = 44’ W
MD = 31° 33’ W + 44’ W
 
= 31° 77’ W of TN
 
= 32° 17’ W of TN

  Worked example 5: When the 
change is eastwards and the 
change is greater than the minutes 
in the MD
If the mean annual change has minutes greater than the minutes in the magnetic 
declination, you need to borrow a degree in the magnetic declination and convert it into 
minutes. Look at the following example: 
MD = 20° 10’ W – 44’ E 
Before you can subtract the mean annual change of 44’ E from the given magnetic 
declination, you need to borrow 1° from 20° and convert it to minutes. This leaves you 
with 19°. Now take the 1° and convert it to 60’ (remember that 1° = 60’). Now add the 
60’ to the 10’. This gives you 70’. Now you can continue with the calculation:
19° 70’ – 44’ E = 19° 26’ W
